title: Multiple issues with Markdown and URL parsing

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

Hey @pisarenko,

Thanks for the report! These are definitely interesting issues, we'll start taking a look right away.

Thank you,


Evan

As for #59469, we addressed the homograph issue, but the issue of misleading people with a second domain after an '@' symbol still persisted, because we believed it was adequate that we would prompt users to read the URL. In the example you gave the second domain was sufficiently obscured that we think it'd be best if we at least highlighted the real target domain (so we'll be fixing that).

I'm not sure I completely follow your second question, but if you're asking whether or not we intentionally don't show the warning page when linking to a hackerone page, that's intentional.

Hey @pisarenko 

Just a quick update; it took me a little longer to get a fix that I was happy with, but hopefully this'll go out by Monday.

Thanks again for your patience!

Evan
so good . send me massage , what you fixed tomorrow.

Hey @pisarenko,

Ran into a couple of snags. I'm pretty confident the fix should release tomorrow, though there's always the possibility of things slipping a little.

Thanks for your patience!


Evan

The fix is now committed, it should be deployed tomorrow, and then we can verify this together. Thanks again for your assistance and your patience!

Hey @pisarenko,

I'm just finishing up my fix for the additional cases you outlined, thanks for being so thorough!
As for #1, that's due to a bug in RedCarpet, so I've filed an issue with them to get it fixed. Because it doesn't pose a security threat as far as we know we can close out this report without waiting on the issue to get resolved.
3 is definitely annoying as well, but again because it's not security related we can close this report before it's resolved. We definitely appreciate the tip though!

Hi @pisarenko, nice researching!
Hi @ebrynne,  
I believe that the point number 3 is a security issue but it's weak,
######POC:
`<https://www.example.com/>`
<https://www.example.com/>
after opening the url
you will find that `www.example.com` is marked in red
`www` is the sub-domain of `example.com`
as `www` is the sub-domain of `example.com`
`<https://example.com\\.hackerone.com>`
<https://example.com\\.hackerone.com>
that's mean `example.com\` is the sub-domain to `hackerone.com`
and that's not true
because that will redirect you to `https://example.com/.hackerone.com`
this bug can be used as social engineering and it's your website fault by marking the wrong destination with red
######Attack scenario:
an attacker can trick a team member by redirecting him to malicious website
by putting in the report  as example
this url
`<http://2130706433\\.hackerone.com>`
<http://2130706433\\.hackerone.com>
and it's hard to believe that http://2130706433/
is an existing website
but it's actually exists it will redirect you to `http://127.0.0.1/.hackerone.com`
the team member may think that `2130706433\` is the sub-domain to `hackerone.com`
thank you!
woops it's fixed never mind tho

I just wanted to say that, this was a security issue, 
and to show how can it be used.
regards

Hi @pisarenko,

The extra cases you've brought up (like `ftp:/hackerone.com@myfuneral.ru`) definitely seem valid so we will work on getting these fixed. We'll provide you with an update once available. Thanks again!

Hey @pisarenko!

I landed a fix to the malformed scheme exploit today (which means [ftp:/hackerone.com](ftp:/hackerone.com@myfuneral.ru)) now highlights correctly!

As for the two other cases, I don't think we're too concerned about straight up invalid URLs, and the localhost case also seems reasonably unconcerning to me (though I'll still find some time to look into it).

Anything else you think we should tweak before we can call this resolved?

Thanks! 


Evan

Thanks for your report @pisarenko!

We decided to add some basic domain highlighting for the very easy cases (e.g. user@domain.com). For some of the more complex/obscure usages of URLs, such as the URL encoding you use above, we aren't going to do any highlighting. The reasoning here is that users will encounter that URL, and think twice before proceeding anyway simply because it is so unusual.

We only intend to address the [basic cases](http://user@google.com/) with our fix, which is an addition on top of the already existing warning on the external user page.

Again, thanks for your report and your diligent work in getting some of the weirder cases right!

You'll be hearing from us about a bounty decision soon.

Hey @pisarenko!

Just got back from vacation, and now I'm catching up on everything I missed. Here are a few initial thoughts on what's been going on:

In regards to #115205, you're right in that the fix for the issue @pikachu reported also fixed the issue that you reported earlier in this thread, the actual issue was distinct. We just implemented a pretty broad fix that happened to catch the issue you submitted as well, kinda by happy accident.

As for the `{F71077}` issue, I had a little trouble understanding what was going on, but I think I get it now. https://hackerone.com/reports/127809 is the example of this, correct? That's what is preventing the report from loading? This is a new issue that's seperate from the current report though, so we'll deal with it in #127827. 

Does that address all your concerns? Please let me know if I've missed something.

Thanks!

Hey @pisarenko!

Thanks for the quick response!

Let me better explain my reasoning behind @pikachu's report. What you reported showed that there was a certain case where our Markdown parser failed to handle links properly and dumped a whole bunch of escaped markdown/html code to the page. It was ugly, but not concerning. In @pikachu's #115205 the issue was that he could nest link generation in such a way that it would break the report page (a distinct and more concerning issue). The way we fixed @pikachu's issue was very broad, we basically just turned off linkification if anything at all looks weird. It was purely coincidental that this also fixed the formatting issue that you reported. Does that make sense? Basically there were two different problems with two different origins, but the fix we applied was so broad that it fixed both anyways.

And sorry for the delay in getting back to you on #127827. We'll get you a response as soon as possible.

Thanks!


EVan

Thanks!


Evan

additional_data.new_title: Multiple issues with Markdown and URL parsing

activities.message:
Sorry for the long delay on this, @pisarenko. We thank you for your report, and welcome future ones like this, especially where the issue could have possible security concerns.

Happy hacking!
Thanks

summaries.content:
This bug encompassed a couple of different issues:
- A markdown formatting issue that presented no security issue but was definitely kinda ugly. (fixed as a side effect of resolving an unrelated bug  #115205)
- An issue with how we highlighted the domain of external links, where URLs that included an '@' symbol (but not in such a way that denoted an authentication component) only highlighted domain-like components after the '@', even if the real domain was included in the section before the '@'. This could let a malicious user use our redirect page to give a false impression to another user of where they were being sent. There were several other edge cases discovered during the resolution of this bug that could result in the wrong segment of the URL being highlighted. (Fixed)
- Another minor issue on profile pages where certain values inputted for the 'website' field would render the 'back to profile' link on the thanks page unclickable (unfixed for the moment. Not a security concern but will get fixed up eventually).

It's worth noting that in the case of the URL highlighting issue, there are still some cases where we don't highlight any domain, particularly in situations where the URL is not valid but is manipulated by certain browsers into a valid url (chrome does some crazy re-interpretation in certain cases). In cases where our users are being redirected to an external page but we cannot highlight the domain of the website to which they are being redirected, we ask that they take extra effort to scrutinize the link and determine its legitimacy,
